Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Reset \Re*set"\ (r?-s?t"), n. [OF. recete, recepte, a receiving. Cf. {Receipt}.] (Scots Law) The receiving of stolen goods, or harboring an outlaw. --Jamieson. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Reset \Re*set"\ (r?-s?t"), v. t. To set again; as, to reset type; to reset copy; to reset a diamond. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Reset \Re"set\ (r?"s?t), n. 1. The act of resetting. [1913 Webster]
2. (Print.) That which is reset; matter set up again. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Reset \Re*set"\, v. t. (Scots Law) To harbor or secrete; to hide, as stolen goods or a criminal. [1913 Webster]
We shall see if an English hound is to harbor and reset the Southrons here. --Sir. W. Scott. [1913 Webster]

reset n : device for resetting instruments or controls v 1: set anew; "They re-set the date on the clock" 2: set to zero; "reset instruments and dials" 3: adjust again after an initial failure [syn: {readjust}] [also: {resetting}]
